content: No information provided. Dr. Dorothy Irene Height, born in 1912, was a prominent civil rights activist known for her efforts in promoting equality, social justice, and human rights. She advocated for interracial schooling, voter education, and women's rights. Dr. Height also worked to improve the lives of inner-city children and made significant contributions to the advancement of women and African Americans. Dr. Height's public career spans over 65 years, during which she was a valued consultant on human and civil rights issues to First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt. She encouraged desegregation of schools and the appointment of African-American women to subCabinet posts. Dr. Height has been President of the National Council of Negro Women (NCNW) since 1957, overseeing 250 local and 38 national groups focused on economic development and women's issues. Under Dr. Height's leadership, the National Council of Negro Women implemented various programs including Operation Woman Power, leadership training for African-American women in the rural South, the Black Family Reunion, and the Women's Center for Education and Career Advancement to empower minority women in nontraditional careers. Dr. Height has been a leader in AIDS education globally and has helped improve conditions for women in developing countries. She has also played a significant role in enhancing the efficiency and global focus of Delta Sigma Theta sorority and the Young Women's Christian organization. Dr. Height, a member of the "Big Six" civil rights leaders, was the only female at the table during planning for the civil rights movement. She received the Spingarn Award for her civil rights contributions. Dr. Height received several prestigious awards for her civil rights contributions, including the Presidential Medal of Freedom from President Clinton, the John F. Kennedy Memorial Award, the Ministerial Interfaith Association Award, the Lovejoy Award, the Ladies Home Journal Woman of the Year Award, and the William L. Dawson Award. Dr. Dorothy Height received the William L. Dawson Award from the Congressional Black Caucus, the Citizens Medal Award from President Reagan, and the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Freedom Medal from the Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt Institute for her decades of public service to people of color and women. She has left a lasting legacy of public service that has greatly contributed to the progress of the Nation. The President is authorized to present a gold medal to Dr. Dorothy Irene Height for her contributions to the Nation. The Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike the medal. Duplicates in bronze may be sold under regulations set by the Secretary. The gold medal will have national status. The medals authorized under this Act are national medals for purposes of chapter 51 of title 31, United States Code. An amount not to exceed $30,000 is authorized to be charged against the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund to pay for the cost of the medal. Amounts received from the sale of duplicate bronze medals will be deposited in the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund.
